content.webTitle: Household financial confidence increases due to rise in job security

fields.headline: Household financial confidence increases due to rise in job security
fields.bodyText: British households feel more confident about their finances than three years ago thanks to more job security, but the squeeze on pay continues according to the latest household finance survey by data company Markit. Chiming with reports that real wages have tumbled by an unprecedented amount in recent years, it finds that incomes took another knock this month. Overall, three times as many households said their finances worsened in June against those who saw an improvement. But that was a less downbeat picture than in previous months and left the headline balance on the Markit Household Finance Index at 40.8 in June – the strongest reading since February 2010. It was the joint-highest since the survey began in 2009. "Improving household finance trends are an early indication that the UK economy has continued to strengthen in June. Households' perceptions of financial stability are now at a level unsurpassed over the past 4½ years," said Tim Moore, senior economist at Markit. "Better labour market conditions helped reinforce the upturn in households' financial expectations during June, as rising levels of workplace activity translated into diminishing job insecurities." But as workers accept lower pay and shorter hours to hang on to their jobs, more households reported a fall in income – the sharpest drop in wages since January. Markit said workers in the construction and retail sectors faced the biggest drops this month. The report follows research from the Institute for Fiscal Studies last week that said workers have suffered more financial pain since 2008 than in any five-year period of the modern age. Describing this downturn as the longest and deepest slump in a century, the IFS said workers have suffered pay cuts of 6% in real terms over the last five years. Workers report accepting pay cuts to keep their jobs, leaving them stretched by rising household bills and soaring food prices. The TUC claimed last week that the UK's annual pay packet had shrunk by £52bn since the start of the financial crisis.
